We consider a set of dependent integral transformations on a function \\( u(x) \\) defined by the equations \\( v(x) = \\int_0^x u(s) e^{-s} ds \\) and subsequently \\( w(x) = \\int_x^\\infty v(t) dt \\). The transformation from \\( u(x) \\) to \\( w(x) \\) involves a mixing of the cause and effect through double integration, one being definite from 0 to x and the other from x to infinity.

Does the calculation of \\( w(x) \\) for x = T depend exclusively on the behavior of \\( u(x) \\) on the interval [0, T] without considering any values outside this interval?
Explanation: The value of \\( w(x) \\) at x = T includes contributing values from both \\( v(t) \\) where t ranges from T to infinity. Thus, it requires not only \\( u(x) \\) available from [0, T] but also from the entire function domain due to the extended limits in the second integral.
